batchInfo.topic: Related Party Transactions and Going Concern

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a related party?

options.B: An affiliate company under common control
options.C: A major supplier with arm's-length transactions

questions.explanation: Related parties include affiliates, principal owners, management, members of their immediate families, and entities in which the company has investments with significant influence.
questions.tip: Related parties: affiliates, owners, management, their families.

questions.question: Related party disclosures must include:

options.B: Nature of relationship, description of transactions, dollar amounts, and amounts due to/from

questions.explanation: Related party disclosures include: the nature of the relationship, a description of transactions, dollar amounts, and receivables/payables with related parties.
questions.tip: Disclose: relationship, description, amounts, balances.

questions.question: Can an entity represent that related party transactions were conducted on arm's-length terms?

options.B: Only if it can be substantiated

questions.explanation: An entity should not represent that related party transactions were conducted on arm's-length terms unless the representation can be substantiated by comparison to similar third-party transactions.
questions.tip: Arm's-length claim: only if you can prove it.

questions.question: For entities under common control, disclosures of related party transactions:

options.B: Are required even if consolidated financial statements are presented
options.C: Are only required in consolidated statements

questions.explanation: Related party relationships and transactions are disclosed even in consolidated financial statements because transactions with commonly controlled entities not in the consolidation affect the financial statements.
questions.tip: Disclose related party info even in consolidated statements.

questions.question: Compensation arrangements with management are:

options.A: Always related party transactions requiring disclosure
options.B: Not considered related party transactions
options.C: Disclosed only if above market rates

questions.explanation: Compensation arrangements, expense allowances, and similar items in the ordinary course of business are generally excluded from related party disclosure requirements.
questions.tip: Normal compensation = not a related party transaction.

questions.question: The nature of a control relationship must be disclosed:

options.B: Even if no transactions occurred during the period

questions.explanation: The nature of control relationships must be disclosed even if no transactions occurred between the parties during the period.
questions.tip: Control relationship: disclose even without transactions.

questions.question: The going concern assumption means:

options.A: The entity will liquidate within one year
options.B: The entity will continue operating for the foreseeable future

questions.explanation: Going concern assumes the entity will continue operating for the foreseeable future without the intent or necessity to liquidate, cease trading, or seek protection from creditors.
questions.tip: Going concern = entity will keep operating.

questions.question: Management must evaluate going concern for a period of at least:

options.A: Six months from the balance sheet date
options.B: One year from the date financial statements are issued (or available to be issued)

questions.explanation: Management evaluates whether substantial doubt exists about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern for one year from the date financial statements are issued or available to be issued.
questions.tip: Going concern period: 1 year from issuance date.

questions.question: Substantial doubt about going concern exists when:

options.B: It is probable the entity cannot meet obligations as they become due within one year

questions.explanation: Substantial doubt exists when conditions and events indicate it is probable the entity will be unable to meet its obligations as they become due within one year of financial statement issuance.
questions.tip: Substantial doubt: probable can't meet obligations.

questions.question: When substantial doubt exists, management's plans are evaluated to determine if they will:

options.B: Mitigate the conditions to make it probable the entity can meet obligations
options.C: Generate profits in the next quarter

questions.explanation: Management considers whether plans will effectively mitigate the adverse conditions so it becomes probable the entity will be able to meet its obligations for one year.
questions.tip: Plans must make meeting obligations probable.

questions.question: If substantial doubt exists but is alleviated by management's plans, the entity must disclose:

options.B: The conditions that raised substantial doubt and management's plans
options.D: A going concern emphasis paragraph only

questions.explanation: Even when management's plans alleviate substantial doubt, disclosure is required: the principal conditions/events that raised doubt and management's evaluation and plans to address them.
questions.tip: Doubt alleviated: still disclose conditions and plans.

questions.question: If substantial doubt is NOT alleviated after considering management's plans, additional disclosures include:

options.A: Only a statement that doubt exists
options.B: Statement that substantial doubt exists about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern

questions.explanation: When substantial doubt is not alleviated, disclosure includes an explicit statement that there is substantial doubt about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern within one year.
questions.tip: Doubt NOT alleviated: explicit doubt statement required.

questions.question: Which is typically a condition that could raise substantial doubt about going concern?

options.B: Recurring losses and negative cash flows from operations

questions.explanation: Recurring operating losses and negative cash flows, along with working capital deficiencies, loan defaults, and loss of major customers, are conditions that may indicate going concern issues.
questions.tip: Red flags: losses, negative cash flow, defaults, customer loss.

questions.question: An entity should use liquidation basis of accounting when:

options.B: Liquidation is imminent
options.D: Revenue declines for two consecutive years

questions.explanation: Liquidation basis is used when liquidation is imminentâ€”either when a plan for liquidation is approved and there are no significant barriers, or when liquidation is imposed by other forces.
questions.tip: Liquidation basis: only when liquidation is imminent.

questions.question: Common related party transactions include:

options.B: Loans to officers, purchases from affiliates, guarantees of affiliate debt

questions.explanation: Common related party transactions include: loans to/from officers and shareholders, sales/purchases with affiliates, and guarantees of related party debt.
questions.tip: Related party: loans to officers, deals with affiliates, guarantees.

questions.question: For management's plans to alleviate going concern doubt, the plans must be:

options.B: Probable of being effectively implemented and resolving the doubt

questions.explanation: Plans must be probable (likely) of being effectively implemented, and it must be probable that the plans will mitigate the conditions raising doubt.
questions.tip: Plans must be probable of success, not just possible.

questions.question: Related party relationships are particularly important in evaluating VIEs because:

options.B: Related parties may collectively be a de facto agent requiring consolidation
options.C: Related party transactions are prohibited with VIEs

questions.explanation: In VIE analysis, related parties may act together as a de facto agent. If related parties together have the characteristics of a primary beneficiary, one party may need to consolidate.
questions.tip: VIE: related parties together may trigger consolidation.

questions.question: The responsibility for evaluating going concern rests with:

options.B: Management, with the auditor evaluating management's assessment

questions.explanation: Management is responsible for evaluating whether substantial doubt exists and making disclosures. The auditor evaluates whether management's assessment is reasonable and disclosures are adequate.
questions.tip: Going concern: management's responsibility, auditor evaluates.

questions.question: An equity method investee is considered a related party because:

options.B: The investor has significant influence over the investee
options.C: Any investment creates a related party

questions.explanation: Entities over which the reporting entity has significant influence (typically 20-50% ownership) are related parties because of the ability to influence operating and financial decisions.
questions.tip: Equity method = significant influence = related party.

questions.question: A favorable subsequent event (like securing new financing) that alleviates going concern doubt occurring before issuance:

options.A: Eliminates the need for any disclosure
options.B: Should be considered in the going concern evaluation
options.C: Is ignored because it occurred after year-end

questions.explanation: Subsequent events through the issuance date, including favorable events like securing financing, are considered in the going concern evaluation and may affect whether substantial doubt exists.
questions.tip: Going concern considers subsequent events through issuance.
